Arguments For:
1. Th2 cells are associated with immune tolerance: Th2 cells are known to play a role in immune tolerance, which is the ability of the immune system to distinguish between self and non-self. In the context of SLE, an Th2 cell environment may help to prevent the immune system from attacking the body's own tissues.
2. Th2 cells produce anti-inflammatory cytokines: Th2 cells produce cytokines such as interleukin-4 (IL-4) and interleukin-10 (IL-10), which have anti-inflammatory properties. In SLE, an Th2 cell environment may help to reduce inflammation and prevent tissue damage.
3. Th2 cells are less prone to activation-induced cell death: Th2 cells are less prone to activation-induced cell death compared to Th1 cells, which are more prone to undergoing apoptosis (cell death) upon activation. This may help to maintain a stable Th2 cell population in SLE patients.
Arguments Against:
1. Th2 cells can also promote inflammation: While Th2 cells are known to produce anti-inflammatory cytokines, they can also promote inflammation through the production of pro-inflammatory cytokines such as IL-22. In SLE, an Th2 cell environment may contribute to the development of inflammation and tissue damage.
2. Th2 cells may not be present in all SLE patients: Some studies have shown that Th2 cells are not present in all SLE patients, or that their numbers are reduced in these patients. This may suggest that an Th2 cell environment is not a universal feature of SLE.
3. Other factors may also contribute to disease development: While an Th2 cell environment may play a role in impeding disease development in some SLE patients, other factors such as genetic predisposition, environmental triggers, and immune dysregulation may also contribute to the development of the disease.
